This is some of the lowest levels going back 3 years.  Extremely low fear levels out there.  put call ratio falling off a cliff.  no one needs protection anymore.  at some point here we get a little exuberant.  but hard to argue with seasonal strenth, santa rally, CTA and Vol targeting buying (remember they buy more when volatility drops), corporate buybacks etc...   The risk gauge historically has spent about 51% of the time between 35 and 65, 19% above 65 and 30% below 35 where we are now.  so it CAN stay low.  rarely below 20.  but in the low 20s premiums are going to get pretty darn thin

By the way over 5 years SVXY has a beta of 1.67 to the SPY.  the idea of the PureVol is to sidestep the bad drawdowns, as it did recently.  Will it grab the top or bottom?  Never.  but the idea is to step aside when fear hits a higher and more durable level, and wait for better days.   And then ride the wave higher when the coast is clear (ie now).  Charlie Munger said if you can't handle 50% drawdowns once in awhile you shouldn't be an equity investor.  Ok, maybe true, hard to argue with one of the great ones.... but what if you can avoid a bunch of that drawdown?

message.content:
We've talked about hedging. From the options bible for everyone's review:
> VIX CALLS ARE A BETTER PORTFOLIO HEDGE THAN SPX PUTS
> The simple reason that VIX calls are a better hedge for a broad-based equity portfolio is that they provide dynamic protection, whereas SPX puts do not. To demonstrate this, consider the following:
> Example: In June, with SPX at 1530, a portfolio manager decides that he wants to buy SPX puts as a hedge. He chooses the December 1400 puts-approximately 8% out of the money. After the protection is purchased, suppose that the stock market has a strong summer rally. By early September, SPX has reached 1700. The puts that were bought for protection are now 300 points out of the money at perhaps the time they are most needed— entering the fall of the year (traditionally a rough time for stocks). The problem is that the put strike was fixed and, when the market rose, the protection became less and less valuable. At this point, one would have to either buy more protection at a more reasonable distance out of the money (8%-10%) or forsake the protection altogether.
> It is for the reason shown in this example, that many portfolio managers eschew buying puts as protection, for they lose their protective ability when the market rallies.
> The same thing does not occur with VIX options. Consider the same portfolio manager in the following example, but now he decides to buy VIX call options as protection.
> Example: In June, with SPX at 1530, and with VIX trading near 15, a portfolio manager decides to buy VIX calls as a hedge. He chooses the December 20 calls. That is, they will provide protection if VIX climbs above 20 by expiration. This is only likely to happen in a sharp market decline, but VIX normally spikes into the mid-30s and higher during a sharp market decline-even when it starts from such a low level.

content: This is from that book

message.content:
fwiw the full list of choices is
1. index puts
2. put spreads (explicitly not recommended because it caps your protection)
3. index calls
4. collars
5. futures
6. vol derivatives

content: I open every month one new ladder with 120 DTE. Therefore, I sell one Delta 80 Call and buy two Calls with one point difference (e.g. sell 1 call 14 vix and buy one call 17 vix and one call 18 vix). The idea is that the sold call finace the two bought calls. In total then I will have always 4 vix call ladders open.

Sorry guys...I'm totally ignorant about this VIX trade. If I sell a put on the VIX what is getting assigned? Is it cash settled? if yes, what is the conversion? I'm talking about selling option on VX on Fidelity not the future. Thanks.
cash
VIX options are all tied to their own future.  So dec options are dec future.   and the VIX future is trying to 'predict' where the VIX will be on expiry.  the future will collapse into the cash VIX.
it's a whole different animal
I'm looking at Feb 25. If I sell a put 16 the premium is 1.67 (Barchart). is the 16 VIX = 1600$?
it's where VIX is that determines where you are.  So you'll receive 1.67x100=$167.  breakeven is 14.33
VIX settlement versus strike.  so if it settles at 15 (not same expiry as stocks, usually the Wednesday before) you'll make 67$
cash settled
VIX settlements have been known to be whacky so usually people close before the morning settlement (day before)
SVXY making about 16 cents a day

Last year there was a mini sell-off first week of January for no reason. Some stocks recovered immediately and went on the bull train, but tickers such as TSLA fell a bunch and continued to fall until May. The "I am OK to be assigned" people were bag holding their puts at 240 while the stock went to 150.

referenced_message.content: can we trust this number with low volume today and this week?

content: Not sure what your response has to do with my question. That said, those "i am okay to be assigned" people are probably laughing their asses off right now sitting on TSLA shares at 450+ that they were assigned at 240.

referenced_message.content: Last year there was a mini sell-off first week of January for no reason. Some stocks recovered immediately and went on the bull train, but tickers such as TSLA fell a bunch and continued to fall until May. The "I am OK to be assigned" people were bag holding their puts at 240 while the stock went to 150.

content: sorry my answer to your question is that sometimes vol can be treacherous. wrt to the people who were assigned at 240 most of them panic closed. and the TSLA stock could have gone very differently with a different election outcome, the faith in the fundamentals of the company has little to do with the stock current trajectory.
no judgment bag holding is very stressful. I panic closed a bunch of positions on Aug 5 and it has been a scathing lesson as well.

Ah, yes, volatility can definitely be very treacherous. wrt to the people who were assigned at 240, we actually can't say if they panic sold or not ... we don't know unless you know everyone that got assigned at 240 and what they did with that position.

referenced_message.content: sorry my answer to your question is that sometimes vol can be treacherous. wrt to the people who were assigned at 240 most of them panic closed. and the TSLA stock could have gone very differently with a different election outcome, the faith in the fundamentals of the company has little to do with the stock current trajectory.

content: if anything ... remember, investing is a long-term game ... and if you are "okay to be assigned" its because you believe in the long-term viability of the stock, you understand the short-sightedness and overreaction of traders and the stock market, and you play the long game with a long-term perspective in mind, not a short-term outlook/reaction

hence, only sell puts on stocks you don't mind owning and are okay with being assigned at strike prices that you are okay owning at (assuming you've done your research and due diligence to understand what pricing would be fair and how markets tend to overreact in the short-term and then correct in the long-term)

Yes, no matter how many ways we slice and dice it usually comes down to the stock, and are you ok with it.  as I always say.... all roads lead back to the stock, so you'd better like it.  and proper sizing, cause every now and then one of those will still go to zero!

referenced_message.content: hence, only sell puts on stocks you don't mind owning and are okay with being assigned at strike prices that you are okay owning at (assuming you've done your research and due diligence to understand what pricing would be fair and how markets tend to overreact in the short-term and then correct in the long-term)

content: Hey Dan, sorry it looks like I offended you personally. I was not trying to make fun of or paint the "happy to be assigned" people as stupid. Just an example of how we can feel confident about a position and the next week hate to have it.

referenced_message.content: Ah, yes, volatility can definitely be very treacherous. wrt to the people who were assigned at 240, we actually can't say if they panic sold or not ... we don't know unless you know everyone that got assigned at 240 and what they did with that position.

content: I'm not offended. Just wanted to point out some facts about the "happy to be assigned" folks. Think of it on the flip side ... there could be a lot of folks who diss the "happy to be assigned" folks and don't play their game, but then they miss out on getting assigned and then miss out on a massive rally in the stock afterwards. I've had that happen a few times and I regret that more than I regret not getting assigned at a higher price, letting the stock dip more below the strike, but then at least being in the stock to take part in the 2,3,4,5...10X rally afterwards.

referenced_message.content: Hey Dan, sorry it looks like I offended you personally. I was not trying to make fun of or paint the "happy to be assigned" people as stupid. Just an example of how we can feel confident about a position and the next week hate to have it.

content: happened to me and one of my learnings from it is that if I like the stock at its price, buying it works just as well.
totally ... so many ways to play the game ...

referenced_message.content: happened to me and one of my learnings from it is that if I like the stock at its price, buying it works just as well.

for newbies, this number is a complex metric fear/risk type measure that takes into account many things like VIX futures curve shape, VRP, VIX oscillators etc...   above 60 is caution, above 65-70 is very worried, above 80 is PLAY the swings with long vol (always have a piece of long gamma to play with if you must get involved, but in all likelyhood you're in defense mode putting out a few fires).  under 60 is good, under 50 is getting really calm and you can expect generally calm markets, buy the dip selloffs (like we've been seeing) etc..
under 30, starting to get too calm.  ie ref my Volatility Ninja Series (for those who've done my programs) explains that in detail in lesson 4 I believe.
So 35-55 is a kind of sweet spot
In the QE era (2010-2019) under 20 would have been too calm.  We are in a new volatility regime now so 30 would be my lower bound
I taught this 2 weekend ago that 0.75 on the VIX9day versus VIX gets a little quiet.   good to watch
